    <item>
      <title>Campaign catchup: leaders go head-to-head in front of election diehards</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/campaign-catchup-leaders-head-to-head-election-diehards</link>
      <description><p>Malcolm Turnbull and Bill Shorten prepare to face off in the first election debate in Windsor, north-western Sydney, writes <strong>Elle Hunt</strong></p><p>TGIF, all. Spare a thought for <strong>Malcolm Turnbull </strong>and <strong>Bill Shorten</strong>, oh-so-close to the end of their first week of the election campaign, but still some hours from being handed the cold one.</p><p>The leaders will shortly go head to head in their first debate, the Sky News People’s Forum, moderated by political editor <strong tabindex="-1">David Speers</strong> and broadcast live from 6pm AEST. They will take questions from 100 undecided voters at the Windsor RSL club in the <a draggable="true" href="http://www.aec.gov.au/profiles/nsw/macquarie.htm">marginal seat of Macquarie</a> in north-western Sydney, which has been held by Liberal backbencher <strong tabindex="-1">Louise Markus</strong> since 2010.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Sneaky email from Bill Shorten asking me over for SkyNews and chill. <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/AusPol?src=hash">#AusPol</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/SkyNews?src=hash">#SkyNews</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/PeoplesForum?src=hash">#PeoplesForum</a> <a href="https://t.co/m4KzF27H21">pic.twitter.com/m4KzF27H21</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Blessed are the innovators <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/zOp8Ww8oZi">pic.twitter.com/zOp8Ww8oZi</a></p><p>It punishes those voters who vote for minor parties by threatening to kill off their votes and the fact that we had a fair hearing here in the high court ... I’m satisfied that we do have in the high court a very, very good system of democracy.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Tomorrows <a href="https://twitter.com/theheraldsun">@theheraldsun</a> front page tonight <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/XbPMCghnfr">pic.twitter.com/XbPMCghnfr</a></p><p>The government extends its condolences to the family of the Australian man over this tragic incident. All appropriate assistance is being provided to his family.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The first kiss of the campaign <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/ausvotes?src=hash">#ausvotes</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/4dy0tgJj7W">pic.twitter.com/4dy0tgJj7W</a></p><p class="text">Sign in to the Guardian site and enter your email address to sign up.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/campaign-catchup-leaders-head-to-head-election-diehards">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Labor hits back at 'not very scary scare campaign' on negative gearing policy – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/video/2016/may/13/labor-hits-back-at-not-very-scary-scare-campaign-on-negative-gearing-policy-video</link>
      <description><p>The shadow treasurer, Chris Bowen, and shadow assistant treasurer, Andrew Leigh, address the media in Melbourne. Bowen says the real estate industry has not released any evidence to back its ‘ridiculous and shrill scare campaign’ <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/labor-hits-back-at-negative-gearing-shrill-scare-campaign-by-real-estate-industry">against Labor’s negative gearing policy</a> and says hundreds of thousands of first-home buyers are being locked out of the market</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/video/2016/may/13/labor-hits-back-at-not-very-scary-scare-campaign-on-negative-gearing-policy-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Duncan Storrar went on Q&A – now his personal life is dragged through the mud</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/duncan-storrar-qanda-personal-life-dragged-through-mud</link>
      <description><p>Storrar found his past was considered fair game in the media after he articulated with disarming clarity how the budget looks from the lowest rungs</p><p>A week ago nobody had heard of Duncan Storrar. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/qa-star-duncan-storrar-may-need-tax-advice-after-crowdfunding-success">How he must wish that was still the case</a>.</p><p>Friday brought fresh humiliation for the 45-year-old father of two. <a href="http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/qa-star-duncan-storrar-exposed-as-thug-as-public-raise-60000/news-story/40fa76230ca09820313a9372de4b0aa9">Melbourne’s Herald Sun dredged up his criminal record</a>, including stints in prison for threats to kill and breaching court orders.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/10/qa-recap-questions-about-trickle-down-economics-open-the-floodgates">Q&amp;A recap: questions about trickle-down economics open the floodgates</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/qa-star-duncan-storrar-may-need-tax-advice-after-crowdfunding-success">Q&amp;A star Duncan Storrar may need tax advice after crowdfunding success</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/duncan-storrar-qanda-personal-life-dragged-through-mud">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Arts workers should be angry about funding cuts – we can't work harder for less</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/13/the-arts-industry-has-the-right-to-be-angry-about-funding-cuts-it-cant-possibly-work-any-harder</link>
      <description><p>Defiance may seem heroic but running full programs with insufficient funding is a risky business. And the burden will fall on the workers</p><p>They’ve been calling the past week <a href="https://dailyreview.com.au/worst-week-ever-australian-arts/42216/">the worst ever</a> for the Australian arts. They’re not wrong.</p><p>The sector’s fears that Catalyst – the newly introduced arts funding program dispensed directly by the government’s arts ministry – would become an exercise of political favour and pork barrelling, seem to have come true. Almost half of the program’s four-year budget has been announced in its first six months, with an extraordinary $13m in grants rushed out as the government went into caretaker mode last weekend.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/commentisfree/2015/may/13/after-the-budget-shh-australias-era-of-artistic-silencing-begins">After the budget: shh! Australia's era of artistic silencing begins</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/may/28/captains-calls-and-culture-war-the-future-of-australian-arts">Captain's calls and culture war: the future of Australian arts | Jeff Sparrow</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/13/the-arts-industry-has-the-right-to-be-angry-about-funding-cuts-it-cant-possibly-work-any-harder">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Labor hits back at negative gearing 'shrill scare campaign' by real estate industry</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/labor-hits-back-at-negative-gearing-shrill-scare-campaign-by-real-estate-industry</link>
      <description><p>Shadow treasurer Chris Bowen says realtors opposed to plan to limit negative gearing to new housing are vested interests with no evidence for their criticism</p><p>Labor has hit back at a campaign against negative gearing changes by a group of large real estate agencies, arguing they are vested interests who have not produced any evidence for their criticisms of its policy.</p><p>The Real Estate Institute of Australia and major realtors, including LJ Hooker, Raine and Horne, Laing and Simmons, McGrath, Ray White and Century 21, have said they are going to campaign against Labor’s proposed changes to negative gearing using their databases of hundreds of thousands of landlords and tenants.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/10/scott-morrison-reserve-bank-warning-negative-gearing">Morrison dismisses Reserve Bank warning about negative gearing</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2016/apr/28/how-negative-gearing-replaced-the-great-australian-dream-and-distorted-the-economy">How negative gearing replaced the great Australian dream and distorted the economy | Greg Jericho</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/labor-hits-back-at-negative-gearing-shrill-scare-campaign-by-real-estate-industry">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Australian election 2016 in pictures: Malcolm, Malcolm everywhere</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/gallery/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-in-pictures-malcolm-malcolm-everywhere</link>
      <description><p>A look back at the first week of the campaign through the lens of Guardian Australia’s roving photographer <strong>Mike Bowers </strong>– who mainly travelled with the prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull. It’s been a week in which the PM has been drinking beer, dodging interviews and stockpiling watermelons ... while Labour leader Bill Shorten has gone back to school</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/gallery/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-in-pictures-malcolm-malcolm-everywhere">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australian-election-2016">Australian election 2016</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australia-news">Australia news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/malcolm-turnbull">Malcolm Turnbull</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/coalition">Coalition</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/bill-shorten">Bill Shorten</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australian-politics">Australian politics</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/labor-party">Labor party</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/liberal-party">Liberal party</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 04:15:09 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/gallery/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-in-pictures-malcolm-malcolm-everywhere</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/f6b5faebada2106d332bec5d7ebed019fe61eb3f/0_283_4500_2700/4500.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=0b497510c60ed48be804ec0080621ecb">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Mike Bowers for the Guardian</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/f6b5faebada2106d332bec5d7ebed019fe61eb3f/0_283_4500_2700/4500.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=dfef88f9d4bd4cd3144086d4e0de6ca6">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Mike Bowers for the Guardian</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <dc:creator>Mike Bowers</dc:creator>
      <dc:date>2016-05-13T04:15:09Z</dc:date>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Nauru refugee and premature baby in critical condition after emergency caesarean</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/nauru-refugee-and-premature-baby-in-critical-condition-after-emergency-caesarean</link>
      <description><p>Baby unable to breathe without aid when flown off the island with Somali mother en route to Australia, immigration department says </p><p>A 22-year-old Somali refugee and her newborn baby have been medically evacuated from Nauru after she underwent a caesarean section a month prematurely.</p><p>The immigration department confirmed the woman and her baby had been transferred to Australia where they were receiving “appropriate medical treatment”, but declined to comment further. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/06/whats-the-end-game-for-australias-border-policy-a-world-of-walled-city-states">What's the end game for Australia's border policy – a world of walled city-states? | Jeff Sparrow</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/nauru-refugee-and-premature-baby-in-critical-condition-after-emergency-caesarean">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/nauru">Nauru</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australian-immigration-and-asylum">Australian immigration and asylum</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/asia-pacific">Asia Pacific</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australia-news">Australia news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australian-politics">Australian politics</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 04:00:24 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/nauru-refugee-and-premature-baby-in-critical-condition-after-emergency-caesarean</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/0a484988f980865364ec69bb476e97430c76e677/0_224_4000_2402/4000.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=d9e9b6966092ed89f351f1b9b27db87f">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Remi Chauvin for the Guardian</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/0a484988f980865364ec69bb476e97430c76e677/0_224_4000_2402/4000.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=00dcc78c20da93338aec4791819bbb38">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Remi Chauvin for the Guardian</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <dc:creator>Helen Davidson</dc:creator>
      <dc:date>2016-05-13T04:00:24Z</dc:date>

    <item>
      <title>Australian election 2016: high court dismisses challenge to Senate voting changes – politics live</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-greens-politics-live</link>
      <description><p>High court rejects Family First senator Bob Day’s case against the government’s changes to Senate voting intended to stop micro parties being elected through complicated preference arrangements<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T03:02:22.267Z">4.02am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The live blog is winding down before being fired up again by <strong>Katharine Murphy </strong>in time for the leader’s debate this evening.</p><p>It’s been a subdued day on the campaign trail for both leader as they deflected attacks that were not from each other. </p><p>Malcolm lives in Sydney, has a harbourside view and has done well in life. Done well, it’s something to be proud of.</p><p>Everyone is entitled to their commentary.</p><p>Now I understand that vested interests will always scream in defence of their particular part of taxpayer subsidy. In Australia, over $10bn a year of taxpayer money goes to subsidise negative gearing. We’re not scrapping negative gearing entirely but we do want to do budget repair that is fair. We don’t think the case is as fair as perhaps some people argue it is. I don’t expect the real estate agents and their lobbies and their scare campaign to be reminding Australians that their profits are built upon the taxes which every Australian pays.</p><p>I don’t want to [do preference deals], I think the most likely scenario is there will be open tickets, we will let voters decide. I think voters are smart enough to decide for themselves … What I’ve heard is maybe Liberal and Labor are talking a preference deal swap to squeeze out anyone running from the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/nick-xenophon">Nick Xenophon</a> Team.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:50:57.550Z">3.50am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Julia Gillard</strong> is speaking in Melbourne at the Women’s leadership forum.</p><p>A few tidbits:</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Former PM Julia Gilliard says "sense of purpose" crucial for leaders <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/AFTS?src=hash">#AFTS</a> "write down what you want to do." <a href="https://t.co/f500smpGda">pic.twitter.com/f500smpGda</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">.<a href="https://twitter.com/JuliaGillard">@JuliaGillard</a> was encouraged to write down her purpose, keep it with her, and reflect on it when says got tough. <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/afts?src=hash">#afts</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">"We've got to be open to constructive criticism by people we trust." -<a href="https://twitter.com/JuliaGillard">@JuliaGillard</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/AFTS?src=hash">#AFTS</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:24:00.241Z">3.24am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Everyone looking thrilled to be in each other’s company:</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">In keeping with Labor's school visits, Penny Wong at the gates of Henley High school. <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/KXTnwpoGke">pic.twitter.com/KXTnwpoGke</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:21:00.772Z">3.21am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Liberal campaign headquarters are distributing quotes from real estate industry leaders about their campaign against the Labor party’s policies on negative gearing and capital gains tax concessions.</p><p>A sample:</p><p>Our research shows property investment isn’t just for the wealthy; 37% of investors earned a combined household income under $100,000. The perception that investors are well-to-do is overblown. We also know that about 30% of our investors would sell if negative gearing was abolished or restricted, so we’re concerned for tenants. Contrary to what the opposition may think, abolishing negative gearing would likely create panic purchasing, with a rush of investors buying up existing properties in the six months before changes are implemented. Often these are the same homes targeted by first home buyers.”<strong> <br></strong></p><p>When you take a blunt and heavy instrument to a complex problem, you are likely to generate a whole range of unintended negative consequences.”</p><p>We have to make it easier for first-home buyers, not harder. This will impact on the aspirations and commitments of a large bulk of Australians.<strong> <br></strong></p><p>It’s not a situation of the haves and have-nots. Overwhelmingly we understand the pressure on affordability, whether it be buying or renting. Our concern is politicians segregating the community by making them believe this will be good for them. We disagree.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:11:15.936Z">3.11am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>I haven’t written much on <strong>Duncan Storrar</strong>, the man on welfare who asked a question on Q&amp;A earlier this week and has since been scrutinised by News Corp Australia newspapers.</p><p>It’s not strictly to do with the election campaign, or politics, but I see in the comments enough of you are interested to warrant a quick post.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Tomorrows <a href="https://twitter.com/theheraldsun">@theheraldsun</a> front page tonight <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/XbPMCghnfr">pic.twitter.com/XbPMCghnfr</a></p><p>It’s all part of legitimate public debate in my view.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T01:49:00.691Z">2.49am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Malcolm Turnbull </strong>has done a shopping centre walk in Adelaide and it looks bonkers. A prime minister wandering through suburbia in the election campaign is as casual as the Duchess of Cambridge on the cover of Vogue (ie way too much effort to look “natural”).</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The chaos of a campaign shopping centre walk, <a href="https://twitter.com/TurnbullMalcolm">@TurnbullMalcolm</a> is in Adelaide seat of Hindmarsh <a href="https://twitter.com/abcnews">@abcnews</a> <a href="https://t.co/Yhexo8O8ii">pic.twitter.com/Yhexo8O8ii</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T01:40:28.614Z">2.40am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>When the finance minister and Liberal campaign spokesman, <strong>Mathias Cormann</strong>, was on the rounds this morning, he was asked about the real estate industry campaign against Labor’s negative gearing policy.</p><p>I haven’t spoken to anyone myself. But let me just say, Labor’s negative gearing policy so-called, would be a disaster for Australia. It would push down the value of property. It will push up the cost of rents and it will be very bad for families across Australia trying to get ahead. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T01:35:44.918Z">2.35am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Turns out <strong>Andrew Bolt </strong>does have a line when it comes to Islam, and that line is a royal commission.</p><p><strong>Pauline Hanson</strong>, who is running for the Queensland seat in the Senate, was on his program demanding a royal commission on whether Islam was really a religion or “just a political ideology”, according to Australian Associated Press.</p><p>Host <strong>Andrew Bolt</strong> seemed shocked at the proposition and said he believed the Australian people should be allowed to make up their own minds on the matter.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T01:15:16.290Z">2.15am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>A 34-year-old Australian security contractor working at the Australian embassy in Baghdad has died, a statement from <strong>Julie Bishop </strong>confirms.</p><p>The government extends its condolences to the family of the Australian man over this tragic incident. All appropriate assistance is being provided to his family. </p><p>I am advised the high level of security is being maintained at the embassy. In light of the ongoing investigation, and out of respect for the man’s family, the Australian government will not provide further comment at this time.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T01:10:26.976Z">2.10am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The shadow treasurer, <strong>Chris Bowen</strong>, has also dismissed the multi-million dollar campaign the real estate industry is preparing to mount against Labor’s negative gearing and capital gains tax policies.</p><p>Now, it’s very interesting that the real estate industry today is not launching or releasing any evidence, any modelling, not one little bit of support for their claims for this ridiculous and shrill scare campaign, threatening recession, house price crashes, house prices will go down but rents will go up, hordes of locusts would come on Australia should negative gearing actually be reformed. Negative gearing needs to be reformed.</p><p>The real estate industry makes it clear, even in the article in News Limited today ,they accept they have a vested interest in keeping the current arrangements. Well I tell you who doesn’t have a vested interest in keeping the current arrangements,hundreds of thousands of first home buyers who are being locked out of the market. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T01:03:11.002Z">2.03am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The ABC is reporting that an Australian contractor has been killed at Australia’s embassy in Baghdad. The foreign minister, <strong>Julie Bishop</strong>, is expected to provide an update soon.</p><p><strong>Malcolm Turnbull </strong>was asked about it earlier but said he could provide no details at the time.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:56:34.908Z">1.56am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Your update from <strong>Tony Abbott</strong>’s campaign trail in north Queensland</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:54:14.566Z">1.54am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Now that is an innovative way into writing about the election campaign</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">we got a guy at Sexpo to paint a picture of Turnbull with his dingus. Looks pretty good imo <a href="https://t.co/6eYHOPIeFS">pic.twitter.com/6eYHOPIeFS</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:51:26.690Z">1.51am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Malcolm Turnbull</strong> said <strong>Bill Shorten</strong> is a dangerous threat to the economy, is that true?</p><p>Mr Turnbull can call me all the names under the sun he likes. What I think is dangerous for the Australian economy is that this government has tripled the deficit. What I think’s dangerous for this economy is that under this government, real wages growth has flat-lined. We’ve got an out-of-touch PM who thinks that the best advice you can give someone [who is] trying to enter the housing market, is to get a rich parent. </p><p>What I’m looking forward to is outlining Labor’s positive policies ... What I’m interested in is listening to people. </p><p>I think I’d put <strong>Mark Latham’</strong>s fashion advice in the same box I put <strong>Scott Morrison</strong>’s.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:45:16.285Z">1.45am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Is<strong> Bill Shorten </strong>worried about the multi-million dollar campaign being mounted by the real estate industry against his negative gearing and capital gains policies?</p><p>Shorten says he will believe the Reserve Bank’s assessment of his policies above major corporate real estate agents “worried about Losing some of the taxpayer subsidies”.</p><p>Now I understand that vested interests will always scream in defence of their particular part of taxpayer subsidy. In Australia,over $10bn a year of taxpayer money goes to subsidise negative gearing. We’re not scrapping negative gearing entirely but we do want to do budget repair that is fair. We don’t think the case is as fair as perhaps some people argue it is. I don’t expect the real estate agents and their lobbies and their scare campaign to be reminding Australians that their profits are built upon the taxes which every Australian pays. </p><p>If I have to choose between supporting a business model which leads to a lucrative commissions for some real estate agents and property speculators funded by taxpayer money, or a choice between them and the young, impressive women we’ve seen who are the finest, who are going to NASA, who are making remarkable steps forward in their science education, if I’ve got to choose between the big end of town and the negative gearing brigade who don’t want their $10bn of taxpayer subsidy in any fashion diminished or the schools and the hospitals of Australia, I choose the schools and the hospitals of Australia every day.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:39:26.476Z">1.39am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>There is breaking news that there has been a shooting of a soldier and an army officer in Iraq. There are reports this is near the army base in Baghdad. <strong>Bill Shorten</strong> says he will seek a briefing.</p><p>Is this a war we should be fighting?</p><p>It is really important, especially in this heated election environment, that the men and women of our defence forces know that where they serve Australia and that their families back here in Australia also know on behalf of the ones they love overseas, Labor and the Coalition are shoulder to shoulder with the Australian people in defeating the sort of terrorism which is ruining literally millions of lives in that part of the Middle East.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:37:21.183Z">1.37am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Bill Shorten</strong> is joined by <strong>Tanya Plibersek </strong>and <strong>Kate Ellis </strong>at his press conference.</p><p>Does Labor want to make maths and science compulsory? Ellis takes that question:</p><p>We want to make sure that every student through to year 12 covers a Stem [science, technology, engineering and maths] subjects, now that means we need a flexible curriculum. We want to make sure that there is enough diversity in Stem that is on offer ... that there is something that interests each and every student. So that doesn’t mean strictly maths, strictly science, but we do want to ensure by 2020 every student is studying Stem through to Year 12. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:32:56.673Z">1.32am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Everyone standing up at once! Now to <strong>Bill Shorten</strong> in the inner-west in Sydney. He has visited another school to talk up Labor’s education policy.</p><p>There’s some debate in Australia at the moment that investing in education, investing in teachers, won’t deliver an economic dividend. Of course it will. In life there are some things which are beyond doubt. A smart, educated Australia will be a prosperous, successful Australia and that is beyond doubt.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:28:51.480Z">1.28am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Crossbench senators are standing up in Canberra after the high court dismissal of the case against the Senate voting reform.</p><p>Family First senator <strong>Bob Day </strong>says the reforms have “taken away voters’ rights”.</p><p>It punishes those voters who vote for minor parties by threatening to kill off their votes and the fact that we had a fair hearing here in the high court ... I’m satisfied that we do have in the high court a very, very good system of democracy.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:25:52.274Z">1.25am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The astute <strong>Paul Karp</strong> has the details of the high court dismissing the Senate reforms case:</p><p>The high court has unanimously rejected Senator <strong>Bob Day</strong>’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/21/bob-day-launches-high-court-challenge-against-senate-voting-changes">challenge of Senate reforms</a>.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:24:46.930Z">1.24am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Malcolm Turnbull </strong>asked almost straight away how he feels about being described by <strong>Peta Credlin</strong> as “Mr Harbourside Mansion”:</p><p>Everyone is entitled to their comments.</p><p>I’m focused on jobs and growth. Australians know the difference between the government I lead and the government <strong>Bill Shorten</strong> wants to lead. The government I lead is focused on them. It’s focused on ensuring our children and grandchildren have great jobs in the future and now. It’s focused on ensuring we get the economic growth that will enable us to enjoy our wonderful lifestyle in Australia now and into the years ahead. That’s my commitment, our economic plan, strong growth, more jobs.</p><p><strong>Bill Shorten</strong> represents a dangerous threat to our economy. Just think about it. This is what <strong>Bill Shorten</strong> is proposing to do. He is going to deter investment. Now all of us agree, that we need more investment ... What<strong> Bill Shorten</strong> is proposing to do is to ban negative gearing, which will reduce investment, reduce property values,and he’s going to increase capital gains tax by 50%. Now capital gains tax is a tax on investment, that is what it is. He is going to increase the tax on investment. Let me tell you, if you want less of something, tax it more. If you want more of something, tax it less. <strong>Bill Shorten</strong> clearly wants less investment. </p><p>There is no doubt people on very high incomes and with very large superannuation accounts will have to pay more tax, OK. That’s the case. We make no bones about that. But it will also mean that people earning, on low incomes, up to $37,000 will not be paying tax on their super contributions. That’s good, that’s fair at that end. </p><p>Adelaide Hills is delightful to campaign in and I look forward to returning to Adelaide.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:11:00.245Z">1.11am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>In Adelaide <strong>Malcolm Turnbull</strong> is announcing the public transport funding flagged by the Adelaide Advertiser earlier today.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Blessed are the innovators <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/zOp8Ww8oZi">pic.twitter.com/zOp8Ww8oZi</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T00:05:26.848Z">1.05am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>News just filtering through that the high court is not holding up senator <strong>Bob Day</strong>’s case against the government’s Senate reforms, which will change how people can vote for the upper house. The reforms are meant to stop minor parties and individuals getting elected on complicated preference deals.</p><p>Day had challenged them but the high court has not ruled in his favour.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T23:53:17.377Z">12.53am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>A look into the campaign trail.</p><p>In Adelaide with the prime minister:</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">AFP joins campus security at Flinders Uni to check ID while the PM is inside <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/ausvotes?src=hash">#ausvotes</a> <a href="https://t.co/hnX3BrU7BH">pic.twitter.com/hnX3BrU7BH</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">At an all girls Catholic college in Five Dock today. Change of scene from the regional Queensland public schools <a href="https://t.co/q4CtBpLJq0">pic.twitter.com/q4CtBpLJq0</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T23:51:58.692Z">12.51am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>I am not as dextrous as <strong>Katharine Murphy </strong>at getting in amongst the comment thread but I have been dipping down there and enjoying most of the conversations. Some thoughts on what some are trying to frame as “class warfare” from TheBBG .</p><p>Many common everyday average people look up to the wealthy as having somehow a great insight into how to improve things because of their prosperity. They cannot grasp that the wealthy focuse on improving their own lots in life, not anyone elses. Peter Morris seems a case in point. Respecting someone for being successful is one thing, but holding them up as models to lead a country for the benefits of all is another.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T23:44:42.571Z">12.44am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Scott Morrison</strong>’s interview with <strong>Jon Faine</strong> continues ... the Institute of Public Affairs and Labor are both campaigning against the government’s superannuation changes. Those are strange bedfellows, surely?</p><p>Our super charges are there, they’re in budget, we’re going forward with it, they’re fair.</p><p>If I reduce taxes in the future are they going to talk about that being retrospective because people thought they were going to be higher in the future? Of course not. This is about earnings in the future, and yes they affect a small minority of superannuants.</p><p>No.</p><p>No, those on top marginal rate account for less than 3% of taxpayers and account for 30% of tax paid, we have a progressive tax system and that means those people on higher incomes end up paying the overwhelming majority of taxes, and that’s the system we have.</p><p>No I haven’t. Off the hand remarks are made from time to time in politics, he hit me back with one of his zingers, so good for him.</p><p>I’m glad you missed me.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T23:37:05.378Z">12.37am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The treasurer, <strong>Scott Morrison, </strong>is now speaking to Jon Faine on 774 ABC Melbourne. He last spoke on the radio program in December 2011 but Faine says he is going to swiftly move on from that point.</p><p>Is it fair for <strong>Peta Credlin </strong>to call <strong>Malcolm Turnbull</strong> “Mr Harbourside Mansion”?</p><p>No. The thing about Malcolm Turnbull is he’s someone who started out in a flat with his single parent dad and over the course of his life he’s been a great success he’s worked hard for the success he’s had ... his story is one that I frankly find inspirational.</p><p>Well I know journalists like to commentate on commentators who commentate on commentators, I’m not going to commentate on that.</p><p>That’s for others to judge.</p><p>I don’t believe so. I’ll leave that to commentators to discuss with other commentators.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T23:02:56.405Z">12.02am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The Queensland energy minister is trying to blow the lid on the government’s election promises before they are ready to announce them.</p><p>It’s a pesky fact of election campaigns – especially long ones – that sometimes you have to telegraph decisions to state government when you actually make them and not when you want to announce them. When the state government is from the other side of the political fence they don’t necessarily want to play ball.</p><p>These studies are an essential first step for the delivery of future water supply – supporting industrial and agricultural development, economic growth and jobs in our regions.</p><p>This decision has been eagerly anticipated by regional communities throughout Queensland.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T22:54:56.688Z">11.54pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The defence of <strong>Malcolm Turnbull</strong> as “Mr Harbourside Mansion” (as dubbed by <strong>Peta Credlin</strong>) has started this morning with the finance minister, <strong>Mathias Cormann</strong>, first out of the blocks.</p><p>He told Sky News:</p><p>Malcolm Turnbull is very much in touch.</p><p>Malcolm lives in Sydney, has a harbourside view and has done well in life. Done well, it’s something to be proud of.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T22:45:48.563Z">11.45pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The New South Wales Senate election ticket order has been announced:</p><p>1. <strong>Sam Dastyari</strong> (Sydney)</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">So much for commitment to country <a href="https://twitter.com/NSWLabor">@NSWLabor</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/VivThomson">@VivThomson</a> <a href="https://t.co/b53GMQ2XAG">https://t.co/b53GMQ2XAG</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T22:33:27.598Z">11.33pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Another day, another election advertisement. Liberals are going hard on the line that some Labor candidates are not enthusiastic, or straight up don’t support, boat turnbacks.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T22:20:01.079Z">11.20pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>There’s still 49 days to go so it is expected that the election campaign is falling off the front pages. Here’s a taste of today’s:</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The Australian front page. Friday 13 May 2016. <a href="https://twitter.com/australian">@australian</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Election2016?src=hash">#Election2016</a> (in print! Digital edition not updated) <a href="https://t.co/tYp2VIBGv6">pic.twitter.com/tYp2VIBGv6</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Financial Review front page. Friday 13 May 2016. <a href="https://twitter.com/FinancialReview">@FinancialReview</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Election2016?src=hash">#Election2016</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/ausvotes?src=hash">#ausvotes</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/ausvotes2016?src=hash">#ausvotes2016</a> <a href="https://t.co/gUxtaskuSt">pic.twitter.com/gUxtaskuSt</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Guardian Australia front page. Friday 13 May 2016. <a href="https://twitter.com/GuardianAus">@GuardianAus</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Election2016?src=hash">#Election2016</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/ausvotes?src=hash">#ausvotes</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/ausvotes2016?src=hash">#ausvotes2016</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/earleyedition">@earleyedition</a> <a href="https://t.co/Zs3v6ZKwOF">pic.twitter.com/Zs3v6ZKwOF</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T22:03:01.311Z">11.03pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>On radio national <strong>Nick Xenophon</strong> is asked about the report in the Australian today that his promises add up to $100bn over 10 years. Is he going to outline how he will fund his promises?</p><p>Absolutely. Even with the constraints of not even a shoestring budget, but a dental floss budget. The piece in the Australian saying it will cost $100bn, there is no basis to that … interestingly [the report is] backed by the Coalition’s friends at the IPA.</p><p>I make no apology for arguing for jobs … what will the cost be of having hundreds of thousands of people out of work? What will the cost be to Centrelink, to reduced tax receipts?</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T22:00:06.204Z">11.00pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Nick Xenophon</strong> is now on Radio National being asked if he has done a preference deal with Labor to get more votes in Jamie Briggs’s seat of Mayo.</p><p>No preference deals have been done.</p><p>I don’t want to [do preference deals], I think the most likely scenario is there will be open tickets, we will let voters decide. I think voters are smart enough to decide for themselves … What I’ve heard is maybe Liberal and Labor are talking a preference deal swap to squeeze out anyone running from the Nick Xenophon Team.</p><p>Despite what some media commenators say I actually consult with candidates.</p><p>I always feel more comfortable having it as a an open ticket … if we’re neither to the left or right philosophically an open ticket is the preferred outcome.</p><p>No not a stunt, I spoke to your researcher yesterday and was asked how I was funding it, I just made the point it’s tough, I’m running on a shoestring campaign, it’s tough.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T21:38:58.316Z">10.38pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>In Adelaide today (<strong>Nick Xenophon</strong>’s town!)<strong> Malcolm Turnbull</strong> will announce federal funding for the $85m train from the city to Flinders University, <a href="http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/national/federal-election/train-from-city-to-flinders-university-and-medical-centre-in-85-million-plan/news-story/3c8f09559d9afa0ccfaccdd08b39a2b1">according to the Adelaide Advertiser</a>.</p><p>The newspaper describes Turnbull as the “public transport loving prime minister” and says the federal government will provide half of the $85m needed, which the Labor state government has been calling for.</p><p>The Tonsley rail line will be extended 650m and will be partly elevated, with a pedestrian and cycle path alongside and a new station next to the FMC.</p><p>It estimates the train would cut travel time by up to 18 minutes by putting commuters on the fast track instead of buses.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T21:27:20.000Z">10.27pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Nick Xenophon</strong>’s new party is projected to give the Liberals a run for their money in South Australia, threatening a couple of sitting politicians both in the Senate and the lower house.</p><p>The media stunt mastermind is remortgaging his house to fund the campaign and t<a href="http://www.theaustralian.com.au/federal-election-2016/federal-election-2016-nick-xenophon-comes-with-100bn-cost/news-story/8ed56332ab031adb7028fcd21512f566?utm_content=SocialFlow&amp;utm_campaign=EditorialSF&amp;utm_source=TheAustralian&amp;utm_medium=Twitter">he Australian has decided to investigate </a>how much he could cost taxpayers.</p><p>With the budget already in a severe state of disrepair, it is essential political parties provide policy costings for taxpayers to scrutinise. Senator Xenophon has yet to offer the public costings, but any reasonable analysis reveals his policies are simply unaffordable. Rather than offer pie-in-the-sky fiscal promises to voters, all parties, big and small, must release credible costings that are fiscally sustainable.”</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T21:03:38.132Z">10.03pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The high court will decide today on Senate voting reform in the case <strong>Bob Day </strong>brought against the government over the legislated changes which stop complicated preference deals which advantage minor parties. I’ll be on hand to bring you that ruling.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T20:56:39.066Z">9.56pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Bill Shorten</strong>’s campaign spokesman has released a brief statement on negative gearing seemingly in response to the Daily Telegraph’s front-page story that the real-estate industry will mount a multimillion dollar campaign against Labor’s negative gearing and capital gains tax discount policy.</p><p>Labor’s housing affordability plan will level the playing field so first-home buyers can compete with property speculators, boost housing supply, while creating tens of thousands of new construction jobs.</p><p>The campaign, dubbed “Your Voice Counts”, claims that 18 million Australians would be affected by Labor’s plans to scrap negative gearing for existing dwellings and its pledge to halve the 50% capital gains tax discount.</p><p>The campaign ads also claim that the plan would be an economy killer.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T20:45:55.522Z">9.45pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>First sighting of <strong>Tony Abbott </strong> on the campaign trail in north Queensland. He was invited to Mackay by <strong>George Christensen </strong>and has been on his best behaviour this week, even endorsing the government’s superannuation plan after previously labelling it a “senior’s tax” when he was prime minister.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T20:41:21.155Z">9.41pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Wonder if Credlin will go the full Latham before the end of the campaign. When's the Brisbane show on?</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T20:40:26.688Z">9.40pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>There are already T-shirts from the Daily Telegraph’s front page earlier this week endorsing <strong>Anthony Albanese.</strong></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Doing our bit behind the scenes to SAVE OUR ALBO! <a href="https://twitter.com/TheTodayShow">@TheTodayShow</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/AlboMP">@AlboMP</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/karlstefanovic">@karlstefanovic</a> <a href="https://t.co/bXGD4EHXth">pic.twitter.com/bXGD4EHXth</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T20:37:42.652Z">9.37pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>I <a href="http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/federal-election-2016/bishop-is-streaks-ahead-in-street-walk-foreign-minister-a-hit-in-campbelltown-20160512-gotip5.html#ixzz48TZQiCLP">very much enjoyed this sketch</a> in Fairfax Media on <strong>Julie Bishop</strong>’s campaign street-walk in Campbelltown yesterday. She was pulled aside by a local for some friendly advice: </p><p>I basically told her about the area. Just about how bad it is. I said ‘people get shot around here, this is not one of them areas you play games in’.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T20:29:07.387Z">9.29pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>A peek inside a television reporter’s essentials on the campaign trail:</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Good morning from Sydney! We like to call this <a href="https://twitter.com/BreakfastNews">@BreakfastNews</a> on the go... <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/ausvotes?src=hash">#ausvotes</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/abcnews">@abcnews</a> <a href="https://t.co/sSBPAIknWX">pic.twitter.com/sSBPAIknWX</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T20:08:00.416Z">9.08pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>We’ve made it! To the end of the first week of an eight-week campaign. So, maybe not time for back-patting just yet. We have the first leaders’ debate this evening, so we are going to ease into the day delicately. I will take you through to lunchtime and<strong> Katharine Murphy</strong> will guide you through from about 4pm, into the debate and all of the analysis after. No better way to spend a Friday night, I am sure you will agree.</p><p><strong>The big picture:</strong></p><p>If it’s known that you were going to do a street-walk in Penrith, the last thing you want to do, Mr Harbourside Mansion, is look like you don’t know and you’re not welcome in western Sydney.</p><p>I would’ve thought, particularly with the prime minister there, that they might have been a bit more agile, a bit more nimble ... if she’s not pump-primed and ready to go with an answer they should have just moved that visit because that’s the key of a campaign team.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Front page of The Daily Telegraph. Real estate giants launch campaign against ALP <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/gKXVKce6JV">pic.twitter.com/gKXVKce6JV</a></p><p>[The company tax cuts] would increase the economy by more than 1% over the medium term, so that is 10 or 20 years.</p><p>Today, you often see leaders confining themselves to one major, morning, media event, to deliver “their message of the day”. The excuse usually being that they are confined by the deadlines of a multiplicity of modern media platforms – nothing to do with pacing themselves, or minimising exposure risks.</p><p>This very limited campaigning clearly restricts the time for serious, in-depth questioning, allowing short, blunt responses to difficult, penetrating questions, and for the politicians to then to move on quickly to the next.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Tomorrows <a href="https://twitter.com/theheraldsun">@theheraldsun</a> front page tonight <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/XbPMCghnfr">pic.twitter.com/XbPMCghnfr</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-greens-politics-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Why are we surprised by every populist politician? Voting for them can be a rational choice | Jason Wilson</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/why-are-we-surprised-by-every-populist-politician-voting-for-them-can-be-a-rational-choice</link>
      <description><p>Commentators perplexed at the inconsistencies of Donald Trump are missing the point. Populist leaders are defined more by their style than their ideology</p><p>For at least the last 20 years, democracies around the world have been regularly subject to a mounting series of populist insurgencies. From France to Venezuela, sharp-elbowed political actors from both the left and the right have railed against elites, flouted the table manners of liberal politics, and are increasingly meeting with electoral success. </p><p>But it seems that every time this happens, it takes commentators by surprise. Witness the worldwide reaction to the rise of Donald Trump. First came denial, with <a href="http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/dear-media-stop-freaking-out-about-donald-trumps-polls/">even empirical journalists resisting what polling is telling them</a>. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-greens-politics-live">Australian election 2016: high court dismisses challenge to Senate voting reforms – politics live</a> </p><p>I grew up in the era of the rise of Hanson. Growing up in Western Sydney, I knew some people who were otherwise pretty reasonable who were sympathetic to Hanson’s message, which I found abhorrent. That’s where the seeds were sown.</p><p>Trump is a good example here. Commentators are tying themselves in knots trying to work out where he stands, and why people don’t care that he’s flip-flopping on tax or abortion.</p><p>Populist performance spits in the face of what is considered appropriate behaviour.</p><p>Media’s seen as part of the humanities, it’s soft, it’s not science, it’s seen as flippant, not the hard stuff. It’s puzzling to me, because I don’t think any citizens experience politics without mediation.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/why-are-we-surprised-by-every-populist-politician-voting-for-them-can-be-a-rational-choice">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>High court rejects Bob Day appeal and finds Senate voting changes are legal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/high-court-rejects-bob-day-appeal-and-finds-senate-voting-changes-are-legal</link>
      <description><p>Justices’ decision notes challenge does not prove voters are disenfranchised and is ‘in truth an argument about the consequences of elector choice’</p><p>The high court has unanimously rejected Senator Bob Day’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/21/bob-day-launches-high-court-challenge-against-senate-voting-changes">challenge of Senate voting c</a>hanges, finding they do not infringe the constitution.</p><p>The challenge was heard on 2 May and disposed of on Friday, clearing the way for the 2 July election using the new voting system.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/21/bob-day-launches-high-court-challenge-against-senate-voting-changes">Bob Day launches high court challenge against Senate voting changes</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2015/sep/23/turnbull-attempts-to-ease-crossbench-angst-over-senate-voting-reforms">Turnbull attempts to ease crossbench angst over Senate voting reforms</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/high-court-rejects-bob-day-appeal-and-finds-senate-voting-changes-are-legal">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Australian security guard killed in shooting at embassy in Baghdad</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/shooting-at-australian-embassy-in-baghdad-leaves-security-contractor-dead-reports</link>
      <description><p>Department of Foreign Affairs recently dismissed claims diplomats at the embassy in the Iraqi capital had been put at risk by cuts to security</p><p> An Australian security contractor has been shot dead at the country’s embassy in Baghdad, the Department of Foreign Affairs has confirmed.</p><p>The 34-year-old man, who has not been named, was an employee of Unity Resources Group, which provides security to the embassy.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/shooting-at-australian-embassy-in-baghdad-leaves-security-contractor-dead-reports">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/iraq">Iraq</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australia-news">Australia news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/middleeast">Middle East and North Africa</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/world">World news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australian-politics">Australian politics</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 01:15:33 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/shooting-at-australian-embassy-in-baghdad-leaves-security-contractor-dead-reports</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/c544a73c54351a2b240229108cd3306501a0f95f/0_229_5184_3110/5184.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=910c590908ddb62f0d6cd1f2e4c81004">

    <item>
      <title>Celebrities protest at 'crazy' redundancy of Age arts critic</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/-readers-complain-the-age-sacking-arts-writer-the-weekly-beast</link>
      <description><p>Geoffrey Rush and Helen Garner petition editor over sacking of Philippa Hawker. Plus News Corp’s finest just can’t leave Waleed Aly alone</p><p>The arts community <a draggable="true" href="https://www.change.org/p/mark-forbes-keep-film-and-arts-writer-philippa-hawker-at-the-age/c">has come out fighting in support of Melbourne critic Philippa Hawker</a>, who was one of 30 journalists to be made forcibly redundant by the Age this week.</p><p>A petition to the paper’s editor-in-chief, Mark Forbes, to retain Hawker, who has been writing about film and the arts since 1997, has been signed by hundreds of readers, including actor Geoffrey Rush, writers Helen Garner and Christos Tsiolkas, comedian Magda Szubanski and broadcaster Phillip Adams. “Philippa Hawker is one of the most astute and engaged of the critics working in Australia. Her dismissal is a stupid and short-sighted decision driven by panic not sense,” said Tsiolkas. Garner said: “This is a crazy waste of a fine talent and decades of experience.”</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/06/the-reason-news-corp-has-it-in-for-waleed-aly-not-sure-sorry">The reason News Corp has it in for Waleed Aly? Not sure, sorry</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/media-blog/2014/oct/23/chris-graham-on-editing-new-matilda-i-have-pissed-off-a-lot-of-people">Chris Graham on editing New Matilda: 'I have pissed off a lot of people'</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/-readers-complain-the-age-sacking-arts-writer-the-weekly-beast">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How the Coalition has failed on three key economic promises | Stephen Koukoulas</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/how-the-coalition-has-failed-on-three-key-economic-promises</link>
      <description><p>Better growth, a smaller deficit and higher wages have failed to materialise, giving the lie to the Liberals’ claim to be superior managers</p><p>Just under three years ago, Tony Abbott launched the Liberal’s 2013 election campaign. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/04/tony-abbott-poised-victory-austalia-elections">The Coalition duly swept to victory</a>, creating a surge of optimism about the economy partly on the back of the promises made during the campaign.</p><p>Three years on, a look back at the Abbott speech at the campaign launch confirms that the Coalition has fallen well short on many of its commitments, but certainly on matters relating to big picture economic issues.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/10/australians-crave-change-but-this-election-wont-deliver-it-david-marr">Australians crave change. But this election won't deliver it | David Marr</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2016/may/12/youre-not-a-bludger-if-you-pay-no-net-tax-in-australia">You're not a 'bludger' if you pay no net tax in Australia | Greg Jericho</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/how-the-coalition-has-failed-on-three-key-economic-promises">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Today's campaign: Peta Credlin snipes at Turnbull as leaders prepare for first debate</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-coalition-greens-labor-briefing</link>
      <description><p>Election 2016: Tony Abbott’s former chief of staff Peta Credlin brands prime minister ‘Mr Harbourside Mansion’ as Mark Latham criticises Shorten’s ‘man boobs’</p><p>We’ve made it! To the end of the first week of an eight-week campaign. So, maybe not time for back-patting just yet. We have the first leaders’ debate this evening, so we are going to ease into the day delicately. <strong>Katharine Murphy</strong> will guide you through from about 4pm<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-greens-politics-live"> on the politics live blog</a>, into the debate and all of the analysis after. No better way to spend a Friday night, I am sure you will agree.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-greens-politics-live">Australian election 2016: Peta Credlin labels Malcolm Turnbull 'Mr Harbourside Mansion' – politics live</a> </p><p>If it’s known that you were going to do a street-walk in Penrith, the last thing you want to do, Mr Harbourside Mansion, is look like you don’t know and you’re not welcome in western Sydney.</p><p>I would’ve thought, particularly with the prime minister there, that they might have been a bit more agile, a bit more nimble ... if she’s not pump-primed and ready to go with an answer they should have just moved that visit because that’s the key of a campaign team.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Front page of The Daily Telegraph. Real estate giants launch campaign against ALP <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/gKXVKce6JV">pic.twitter.com/gKXVKce6JV</a></p><p>[The company tax cuts] would increase the economy by more than 1% over the medium term, so that is 10 or 20 years.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/malcolm-turnbulls-growth-plan-will-boost-national-income-by-just-06-grattan-institute">Malcolm Turnbull's growth plan will boost national income by just 0.6%: Grattan Institute</a> </p><p>Today, you often see leaders confining themselves to one major, morning, media event, to deliver “their message of the day”. The excuse usually being that they are confined by the deadlines of a multiplicity of modern media platforms – nothing to do with pacing themselves, or minimising exposure risks.</p><p>This very limited campaigning clearly restricts the time for serious, in-depth questioning, allowing short, blunt responses to difficult, penetrating questions, and for the politicians to then to move on quickly to the next.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Tomorrows <a href="https://twitter.com/theheraldsun">@theheraldsun</a> front page tonight <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/XbPMCghnfr">pic.twitter.com/XbPMCghnfr</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/australian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-coalition-greens-labor-briefing">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Turnbull's jobs plan will boost national income by just 0.6%, says Grattan Institute</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/malcolm-turnbulls-growth-plan-will-boost-national-income-by-just-06-grattan-institute</link>
      <description><p>Thinktank says economic effects of $48bn 10-year program of company tax cuts could be negative in short term</p><p>Malcolm Turnbull’s jobs and growth plan will boost national income by 0.6% at most and that benefit will take decades to happen, according to a leading economist.</p><p>A day after the Coalition accused Labor of “lying” about the economic benefits of its education spending, it stands accused of overstating the economic benefits of its $48bn 10-year program of company tax cuts – the centrepiece of Turnbull’s budget and its election campaign.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/campaign-caustralian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-coalition-greens-labor-catchup">Campaign catchup: Shorten celebrates a birthday and the PM downs a beer</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/election-malcolm-turnbull-grilled-on-family-tax-benefit-cuts-by-single-mother">Australian election 2016: Malcolm Turnbull grilled on family tax benefit cuts</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/malcolm-turnbulls-growth-plan-will-boost-national-income-by-just-06-grattan-institute">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Campaign catchup: Shorten celebrates a birthday and the PM downs a beer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/campaign-caustralian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-coalition-greens-labor-catchup</link>
      <description><p>The main party leaders hit the stump in Queensland and Melbourne, but the ghost of a prime minister past just won’t go away, writes <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/profile/elle-hunt">Elle Hunt</a></p><p>To the news of the day: happy 49th birthday, <strong>Bill Shorten</strong>! Asked <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2016/may/12/australian-election-2016-malcolm-turnbull-named-in-panama-papers-politics-live?page=with:block-5733e08ae4b0b748a3b12c23#block-5733e08ae4b0b748a3b12c23">what he was getting</a>, he said: “My present is standing right next to me”, gesturing to his wife, <strong>Chloe</strong>. Aww/eww – delete as necessary. No word on whether <strong>Malcolm Turnbull</strong> being named in the Panama Papers counts as a gift.<br></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Thanks for the birthday wishes everyone. It was great to be able to spend the day with <a href="https://twitter.com/chloeshorten">@chloeshorten</a> <a href="https://t.co/T18bYvGaIr">pic.twitter.com/T18bYvGaIr</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Fantastic photos from today of very popular Tony Abbott surrounded by locals!<br>From <a href="https://t.co/tKnPplWJ3T">https://t.co/tKnPplWJ3T</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash">#auspol</a> <a href="https://t.co/W79Pye7hTE">pic.twitter.com/W79Pye7hTE</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">PM Turnbull tours a brewery in Morningron <a href="https://twitter.com/murpharoo">@murpharoo</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/GuardianAus">@GuardianAus</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/politicslive?src=hash">#politicslive</a> <a href="https://t.co/wBjbbTADHZ">pic.twitter.com/wBjbbTADHZ</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/campaign-caustralian-election-2016-turnbull-shorten-coalition-greens-labor-catchup">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Australian budget 2016 hits poor families hardest, modelling shows</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/australian-budget-2016-hits-poor-families-hardest-modelling-shows</link>
      <description><p>Australian National University analysis shows lowest 20% of income earners lose 1.5% of disposable income and the highest 20% lose 0.2%</p><p>The 2016 budget hit poor families hardest even though high income earners were slugged through tighter superannuation tax concessions, according to new modelling.</p><p>The analysis by Australian National University associate professor Ben Phillips found the main changes in the budget left Australian households $345 a year worse off, on average.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2016/may/07/beware-tax-cuts-for-middle-australia-above-average-earners-benefit-most">Beware tax cuts for 'Middle Australia'. Above-average earners benefit most</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2016/may/12/youre-not-a-bludger-if-you-pay-no-net-tax-in-australia">You're not a 'bludger' if you pay no net tax in Australia | Greg Jericho</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/australian-budget-2016-hits-poor-families-hardest-modelling-shows">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Single mother grills Turnbull over family tax benefits cuts – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/video/2016/may/12/single-mother-grills-turnbull-over-family-tax-benefits-cuts-video</link>
      <description><p>The prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/election-malcolm-turnbull-grilled-on-family-tax-benefit-cuts-by-single-mother">confronted by single mother Melinda </a>outside a factory in Moorabbin, Melbourne. The woman, who didn’t want to give her last name, demanded to know how the PM expected her to pay for her children’s schooling as government plans to strip back family tax benefits</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/video/2016/may/12/single-mother-grills-turnbull-over-family-tax-benefits-cuts-video">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australian-election-2016">Australian election 2016</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australian-politics">Australian politics</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/malcolm-turnbull">Malcolm Turnbull</category>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 07:32:05 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/video/2016/may/12/single-mother-grills-turnbull-over-family-tax-benefits-cuts-video</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/b831c00066f849f885f4b50e9a7b91a65a1556f9/0_83_3827_2297/3827.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=717f950486218b93821f686037b1b2b0">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Lukas Coch/AAP</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/b831c00066f849f885f4b50e9a7b91a65a1556f9/0_83_3827_2297/3827.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=6b88abe131e87fbfb116199f216339d6">
